In the early 1960's I traveled to Dorset and visited one of Hardy's houses (no, I can't remember the town), which had to be approached through a labyrinthine wood where various trees bore little signs on their trunks directing one to the house. The caretaker, to my surprise, was Japanese, as were most of the tourists there that day. I was soon informed of Hardy's popularity in Japan, largely because of his love of nature and vivid depictions of landscape.
Walking one misty morning outside Dorset, I was suddenly interrupted by the sound of hoofbeats, and lo! a woman with flowing black hair galloped past me on a gray steed, seemingly faster than the wind and disappearing into the mist. She was no more than twenty feet away. It sent a momentary shiver through me, since I could swear it was Eustacia Vye.
There are unlocked churches all over Manhattan where one can enjoy a few minutes of quiet respite.

We had a Peter Michael Chardonnay "Ma Belle-Fille" 2010. Sir Peter Michael makes the most Burgundian of all California wines. This one was very nice. I love the names he gives his bottlings. "My daughter-in-law" is named for his son Paul's wife, Emily. The other night we had a bottle of an incredible (Robert Parker 100 point) Peter Michael Pinot Noir called "Ma Danseuse" 2010. It's named for Lady Michael. They met on a dance floor. The names are very cool.

You can only acquire their wines directly from the winery and it takes several years of waiting on a list before you're granted your first purchase. Each year they up your allotment by a few bottles and add some additional wines. The only reason I put up with their Wine Nazi stuff is that these are the best wines California produces, to my taste anyway.

Absolutely. President Theodore Roosevelt warned against the power of big business back in the early 20th century, and worked to enlarge and enhance the federal government in order to stand up to the excesses of the robber barons of industry, and break up the big monopolies of oil, steel and railroads. He felt that if the monopolies were not broken up, big business and big money would run the government, and the US would no longer be a republic.
What is the saying? "Those who do not learn from history are doomed to repeat it".

And the stockholders need to have the power to curb the ridiculously excessive executive pay and perks. The executives have made themselves into a self-perpetuating money machine. They sit on each other's company board of directors, and vote each other huge compensation packages. And as we saw in 2008, that compensation had nothing to do with their performance as executives or the companies' performance.
The executives of the big failing banks and hedge funs walked away with millions, as the taxpayers got stuck bailing out the companies.
Thank you for saying that, I have long felt the same way.

I was just down in the Delta earlier this week--Indianola--home of BB King. I get to go down fairly often. It physically ties the land and agricultural basis of life there to the music of BB and Albert King, Muddy Waters, Robert Johnson, Son house, etc. The two aspects can't be separated. It is a timeless mysterious existence little changed in decades. Huge John Deere tractors, some of the newer ones with rubber treads like tanks, plow the fields. Businesses that support the growing of soybeans, corn, and cotton abound. Very similar to the great farming areas of the San Juaquim and Central Valley areas of California.

I think this single minded devotion to planting and to the harvest in feeding millions is all important in producing the Blues. The field hollers and chants to help forget the endless fatigue of this thankless work was a direct precursor to the Blues. But the Blues does not have to be sad. But visit Beale Street in downtown Memphis on a Saturday night. When the lead electric guitar player starts bending the strings on the high E string you'll feel something your soul stirring in a very deep hidden spot. You'll swear you've somehow been reborn. I guarantee it!!

Pogo-whether right or wrong: the mayor and city council members must live in the city of Baltimore-NOT the county surrounding it with the same name. The police do not have to live in the city.

The reason for the first group is that they represent and work for those who elected them-at least in theory.

The police do not have to live in the city because they are paid to protect and defend as a doctor is paid to diagnose and heal.

The USDA has about 6000 inspectors whose sole responsibility is the inspection of about 6000 US meat plants. There is an inspector in every plant.

The FDA has about 3000 inspectors who are responsible for about 450,000 plants around the world.

A chicken with salmonella (USDA) is not adulterated.

In shell eggs with salmonella (FDA) are adulterated

None of this makes any sense. The problem is not just resources. USDA is no more efficient at preventing outbreaks than FDA despite their greater number of inspections. The President's proposal is a long needed first step.
